stem: A mass casualty incident has occurred at a local concert venue. As the triage nurse, categorize the following clients using the START triage system.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
14:00: Initial report of a mass casualty incident received. Dispatching teams to the concert venue.
14:15: Arrived on scene. Multiple casualties observed. Commencing triage.
14:20: Client A: Found lying prone, RR 34, radial pulse present, unable to follow commands.
14:25: Client B: Ambulatory, minor lacerations, RR 20, oriented to person, place, and time.
14:30: Client C: No respirations after repositioning airway.
14:35: Client D: RR 28, capillary refill >2 seconds, able to follow simple commands.
14:40: Client E: Severe head trauma with obvious skull fracture, agonal respirations, no palpable pulse.
14:45: Continuing triage. Resources stretched. Requesting additional support.
14:50: Client F: RR 10, shallow, capillary refill <2 seconds, able to follow simple commands.
14:55: Client G: RR 0 after repositioning. No pulse noted. 
15:00: Completing initial triage sweep.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: No vitals available. Triage tags are assigned based on rapid assessment at the scene.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No labs available. Triage decisions are made rapidly in the field.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Physical Exam details are documented in the Nurses' Notes.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Care Plans are initiated after triage and transport to medical facilities.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Medication administration occurs after triage and transport to medical facilities.

rows.text: Client A: RR 34, radial pulse present, unable to follow commands.
Client B: Ambulatory, minor lacerations, RR 20, oriented.
Client C: No respirations after repositioning airway.
Client D: RR 28, capillary refill >2 seconds, able to follow simple commands.
Client E: Severe head trauma, agonal respirations, no palpable pulse.

rationale.correct: The correct answers reflect the START triage system, prioritizing clients with immediate life-threatening conditions that are likely survivable with quick intervention. Clients who are deceased or have minimal chance of survival are tagged as Black/Expectant. Ambulatory clients are tagged as Green/Minor. Clients with serious, but not immediately life threatening, conditions are tagged as Yellow/Delayed.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the START triage system and prioritization of care in a mass casualty incident.

answerBreakdown.text: Client A: RR 34, radial pulse present, unable to follow commands.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This client has a respiratory rate >30 and is unable to follow commands, indicating an immediate life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention (Red/Immediate).

answerBreakdown.text: Client B: Ambulatory, minor lacerations, RR 20, oriented.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Ambulatory clients with minor injuries are classified as Green/Minor, meaning they can wait for treatment.

answerBreakdown.text: Client C: No respirations after repositioning airway.
answerBreakdown.rationale: A client who remains apneic after airway repositioning is considered expectant (Black/Expectant).

answerBreakdown.text: Client D: RR 28, capillary refill >2 seconds, able to follow simple commands.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client D has a capillary refill >2 seconds. This indicates a circulation problem that requires immediate attention. This is considered Red/Immediate.

answerBreakdown.text: Client E: Severe head trauma, agonal respirations, no palpable pulse.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This client has agonal respirations and no palpable pulse, indicating a minimal chance of survival. They should be tagged as Black/Expectant.

clinicalPearls: The START triage system prioritizes rapid assessment and categorization of clients in a mass casualty incident.
Respirations, perfusion, and mental status are the key assessment parameters in START triage.
The goal of triage is to do the greatest good for the greatest number of people.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the Yellow (Delayed) and Red (Immediate) categories. Some students may incorrectly assume that any injury warrants immediate attention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific criteria for each triage category, particularly the respiratory rate, perfusion, and mental status assessments.
